stream_context.summary: Kaze resumes work on Course 11’s Bowser corporate tower/oil-rig-themed area, while also showcasing broader polish work done during the week: a new camera control scheme, major reworks to an earlier course’s retro/2D section, and a full overhaul of the on-screen power (health) meter and breath meter rendering/animation. The stream includes active collaboration with Biobak on UI sprites/colors and a Bowser emblem, plus discussion of N64 rendering constraints (alpha-threshold tricks, matrix stack quirks), performance limits on real hardware, and tentative plans for split-screen multiplayer during an upcoming vacation.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces and implements concrete player-facing improvements (new camera controls; new power/breath meter art + smooth animations) and captures Kaze’s design philosophy ("not a meme") plus real-N64 performance constraints shaping Course 11’s overworld scope.

findings.summary: Kaze implemented a new camera control scheme to reduce perceived input lag and improve usability: C-left/right now rotate immediately (no hold-to-rotate), D-pad left/right rotates slowly when held, D-pad up/down and C-up/down handle vertical camera movement, and R recenters the camera behind Mario.

He reworked much of the early-game content compared to the public demo: multiple Course 1 missions were reworked and an earlier retro/2D section was rebuilt with wider walls (to prevent camera squish) and more slide-based traversal intended to mirror how the Mario Bros. 3 underground areas function.

Kaze intentionally shortened the breath meter compared to vanilla Mario 64 to limit free exploration in the underwater/pipe area and encourage using Koopa shells for extended traversal rather than letting players roam everywhere immediately.

Biobak delivered a new power meter (health) sprite set; Kaze and Biobak iterated heavily on the palette to prevent an undesirable brightness jump when transitioning from blue to green (since green reads brighter).

Kaze changed how the power meter renders (including switching to a smaller 32×32 format), then added a scale-in “pop” animation and planned/added smooth refilling rather than chunk-by-chunk updates; he had to resolve matrix stack issues (needing to pop two matrices) after the change initially broke the pause menu.

He explained the N64-friendly technique used for circular meters: using an alpha threshold and multiplying two textures (one being a circular gradient mask) so that increasing the alpha threshold reveals/hides the wedge smoothly with cheap rendering cost.

Kaze noted a newly mentioned microcode option that could disable near clipping, which he believes could resolve some recurring camera/clipping issues (he flags it as something the project may want to adopt).

Real-hardware testing revealed visual wobble from a clip-ratio/clipping setting in this level and also showed a recurring, seemingly random crash that sometimes happens during compilation/building; Project64 can mask/ignore some of these crashes while hardware cannot.
Kaze pushed back on adding Twitch-emote/meme elements to the UI, emphasizing he wants the hack to feel like a coherent game with long-term appeal rather than a joke project.
findings.quote: This is a game, not a meme. I want a game that keeps me occupied for the long term.

findings.summary: Course 11 structure update: the Bowser tower/oil rig area is being staged with multiple star routes; one planned sequence involves the “strike breaker” (a giant Oil Blargg) triggering a cutscene where it eats Mario to transition him into a separate area.

Kaze believes the Course 11 overworld has a hard complexity limit before it starts lagging on N64, so remaining work is focused on essential structures (boss platform/path) rather than continued expansion.

The stream continued the running naming debate for the oil-rig bay area; Kaze set strict naming criteria (rhyme/alliteration) and tentatively adopted the intentionally goofy placeholder name “Oily Boily Bay” because it is memorable and fun to say.
Kaze argued that learning low-level fundamentals matters: he recommends learning assembly before C to properly understand what C is doing under the hood.
findings.quote: Learning C before you've learned assembly is like explaining color to a blind person.

findings.summary: Kaze described the time pressure of balancing ROMhack work with a demanding full-time programming job at a video game company (and mentioned a workout injury reducing training recently), which also explains less frequent streaming.
Kaze and Zeina shared a personal moment about rescuing an injured baby bird over two days (box, towel, food/water) and releasing it once it recovered.

biobak.summary: Provided new power meter (health) sprites and a comparison GIF showing iteration from an overly bright version to a more consistent, darker progression; also coordinated with Kaze on exact color balance.

Proposed/started a Bowser emblem/logo concept sized to work within N64 texture constraints (discussion of mirroring to 128×64 vs 64×64 and the 16-shade limitation for grayscale when using certain formats).
Finished a Buzzy Beetle asset that Kaze planned to import; clarified animation expectations (shell spin handled in-game; model just needs to enter shell state).

zeina.summary: Spoke on-stream about the baby bird rescue and her observations of its recovery; also discussed practical support logistics if Kaze does extended daily streams during vacation (meal prep, bringing food).
Light, candid glimpse of their work-life dynamic: Zeina jokes about needing to escape to her parents during Kaze’s intense work bursts, and that she would manage food if he streams for long hours.

findings.summary: Kaze referenced Lilaa’s upcoming quaternion system as a possible way to add smoother animation transitions (e.g., idle-to-run blending), but said he likely won’t use it for Mario movement because he prefers snappy controls.
Someone informed Kaze about a microcode that can disable near clipping, which he identified as potentially solving camera/clipping issues in the project.
Viewers actively suggested level names (leading to “Oily Boily Bay”), UI animation ideas (flip/coin transition between health and breath), and aesthetic details for the tower building/logo placement.

key_stories.title: Power meter redesign from sprite art to smooth N64 rendering
key_stories.summary: Biobak delivered new power meter sprites, and Kaze rebuilt the rendering pipeline to support the new look and better behavior. The change introduced matrix stack side effects (breaking the pause menu) that Kaze debugged live, ultimately adding a scale-in animation and planning/adding smooth refills.
key_stories.challenge: Make the power meter look cleaner and more consistent in brightness (blue-to-green), while also improving how it appears/refills on N64 without heavy rendering cost.
key_stories.process: Palette iteration with Biobak; switched the meter to a smaller texture footprint; adjusted combiner/texture setup; implemented scale-in behavior using matrix transforms; fixed rendering-state fallout by correctly popping matrices (twice).
key_stories.outcome: New power meter visuals are integrated, darker/more readable than vanilla, and animated; remaining tweaks are mostly polish (e.g., additional depth/segmentation lines if desired).
key_stories.key_quote: This is a game, not a meme. I want a game that keeps me occupied for the long term.

key_stories.title: Breath meter technique: alpha-threshold wedge masking
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrated how the breath meter uses a two-texture setup and alpha thresholding to reveal a circular wedge smoothly. He showed the Blender preview and then validated it on real N64 hardware, noting additional behavior fixes still needed (e.g., refill logic on air).
key_stories.challenge: Render a smooth circular progress meter on N64 hardware efficiently and consistently with the project’s UI style.
key_stories.process: Used a circular gradient mask texture and alpha threshold logic; multiplied textures in the combiner; added a scale-in/popping behavior similar to the new power meter.
key_stories.outcome: Breath meter looks good on real N64; a to-do remains to ensure correct refill behavior when returning to air.

key_stories.title: Camera controls reworked to reduce input lag and friction
key_stories.summary: Kaze replaced the prior camera control behavior (which required holding to rotate and felt laggy/slow) with direct rotation on the C-buttons and slower rotation on the D-pad, plus an R-button recenter. The change is framed as a response to how the old controls felt during play.
key_stories.challenge: Players (and Kaze) perceived the previous camera inputs as sluggish and awkward, especially with delayed rotation.
key_stories.process: Remapped camera rotation and vertical movement across C-buttons and D-pad; added an R-button recenter; tested the feel in-level.
key_stories.outcome: A clearer, more responsive camera scheme that should be easier to learn and reduces the need for “hold to rotate.”

key_stories.title: Naming the oil-rig bay area: committing to a goofy placeholder
key_stories.summary: After multiple streams of suggestions without a clear winner, Kaze set criteria (rhyme/alliteration) and accepted “Oily Boily Bay” as a temporary name because it is fun to say and memorable, even if intentionally stupid.
key_stories.challenge: Find a level name that matches the hack’s naming style and feels satisfying to say/remember.
key_stories.process: Reviewed chat suggestions, rejected options that lacked rhyme/alliteration or felt off-tone, and emphasized the importance of pleasing aesthetics in both visuals and names.
key_stories.outcome: “Oily Boily Bay” becomes the working title, with the bar set: future names must beat it on memorability and style.

key_stories.title: Rescuing a baby bird during development week
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Zeina found a baby bird unable to fly, sheltered it with a towel/food/water, and observed it recovering overnight. They released it once it became active and “chipper” again.
key_stories.challenge: An injured fledgling in the parking lot that couldn’t properly fly away.
key_stories.process: Picked it up, prepared a box, provided warmth and food/water, monitored recovery, and released it when stable.
key_stories.outcome: Bird recovered; the moment serves as a humanizing slice-of-life beat amid technical dev work.

open_questions.context: Kaze remapped camera inputs (C-buttons for direct rotation, D-pad for slow rotation, R to recenter) to address input-lag complaints.
questions: What specific player feedback or internal playtest moments convinced you the old camera scheme had to change?
Did you A/B test the new controls against the old scheme, and what metrics or ‘feel checks’ do you use?
Are there any courses/sections where the new controls still feel problematic (tight interiors, vertical climbs, 2D sections)?

open_questions.topic: Breath meter balancing and exploration gating
open_questions.context: Kaze shortened the breath meter to prevent players from freely reaching everything underwater without using intended movement options like Koopa shells.
questions: How did you decide the target breath duration, and did you tune it per-level or globally?
How do you balance ‘tension’ versus ‘annoyance’ with breath limits in exploration-heavy areas?
What other gates (enemy placement, currents, shell placement) reinforce the intended routing beyond the breath timer?

open_questions.context: Kaze said he’s considering implementing split-screen multiplayer during a two-week break from work at the end of next month, possibly with longer/more frequent streams.
questions: What is the minimum viable version of multiplayer for Return to Yoshi’s Island (camera, UI, stars, physics interactions)?
What are the biggest N64 constraints for split-screen (fill-rate, memory, camera, HUD duplication)?
Would multiplayer be a core supported mode across the whole game or a separate set of levels/challenges?

open_questions.topic: Adopting a microcode that disables near clipping
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned being told about a microcode that can disable near clipping, potentially solving camera/clipping artifacts.
questions: Which microcode is this, and who developed or recommended it to you?
What are the risks of switching microcode mid-project (compatibility, regressions, tooling changes)?
Would this solve the ‘wobbly’ look seen in Course 11, or are there additional causes (clip ratio, fog, projection setup)?

open_questions.context: Kaze implemented scale-in animation and discussed smoothing refills; he also considered additional feedback like sounds when running out and visual segmentation/depth.
questions: What final behaviors do you want for the meters (sounds, flashing, scaling, smoothing speed)?

open_questions.context: Kaze described a dream about collecting Totes that play instruments and decided to implement a version: three Totes hidden across overworlds that perform a song when all are collected.

Will the Totes be a recurring motif tied into the finale/boss encounter later?

open_questions.context: Kaze said they can’t add much more to the Course 11 overworld without lag; the current build is unoptimized and may have worst-case draw order.
questions: What’s your practical performance budget for an overworld on N64 (triangles, materials, dynamic actors)?
What optimization passes are still planned (culling, draw order, LOD, reducing overdraw)?
How do you decide when a visual idea is ‘not worth the fps cost’?

open_questions.context: Kaze hit a recurring crash that “randomly just happens on compilation,” and noted emulator tolerance differs from real N64.
questions: What have you learned about the root cause of the crash so far (toolchain, alignment, memory, undefined behavior)?
How do you ensure builds tested on emulator won’t hide problems that appear on hardware?
Do you keep a reproducible test harness for ‘real N64 sanity checks’ before merging changes?

open_questions.context: Course 11 plans include a strike sequence where a giant Oil Blargg eats Mario and spits him into a separate area; Kaze also referenced uncertainty about the boss-fight ‘final verdict.’
questions: How will the ‘eaten’ transition work technically (warp, cutscene camera, temporary collision changes)?
What is the intended player emotion/beat here—surprise, comedy, punishment, or spectacle?

open_questions.context: Kaze said Lilaa’s quaternion system could enable smoother animation blending (idle-to-run), but he doesn’t want Mario to feel less snappy.
questions: What does ‘snappy’ mean for you in Mario 64 terms (acceleration curves, turn rates, animation timing)?
Where might smoother blending be acceptable (NPCs, cutscenes, bosses) even if Mario stays snappy?
